answers.author: Claire Rygg
answers.text:
Our Monterey History Volunteers are our most important resource for sustaining our history interpretation programs at our Presidio of Monterey and Colton Hall Museums, and and preserving our community’s memories at our California History Room and Archives, all located in Monterey, California. Since the Presidio of Monterey Museum opened in 2001, our dedicated volunteers have greeted our out-of-town and local visitors and have interpreted California’s early history and the founding of the Presidio.  Last year, we celebrated two of our volunteers’ achievements of earning over 1,000 hours of service at our Museum!
The City also has a Community Resources and Volunteer Coordinator who schedules benevolent service and school groups who want to participate in cleaning and maintaining our city’s beaches, parks and outdoor public art. Our Commissions and Boards are comprised of volunteers who assist in recommending action to our city council on how our historic buildings are preserved and how our neighborhoods and parks are maintained.
We hope you will come to Monterey one day and view our beautiful city and explore its rich historic and cultural heritage, and have an opportunity to meet our important assets to our community – our volunteers!

answers.author: John Brooks
answers.text:
Volunteers provide an invaluable service and support a number of City endeavors that are important to the overall efficiency of municipal operations at the City of Thousand Oaks. We use them extensively. One exceptional volunteer working for me developed our Green Business Certification Program. He is an MPA student at USC. I have also had a number of volunteers with BS And Masters degrees volunteer to get City experience and they have allowed us to substantially improve our programs.  I typically have them work on major projects that we are interested in doing, but do not have the time to dedicate to doing the research and development needed.
For the City as a whole, I got the following from our Volunteer Coordinator who just pulled the stats for Volunteer Week. I believe she told me we have over 400 volunteers in various capacities.
Volunteers serve on various boards, commissions, and committees and also work at City Hall and in Theatres, Library, Community Emergency Response Team (CERT), Auxillary Communication Services (ACS), and the Police Department including Volunteers in Policing (VIP), Disaster Assistance Response Team (DART), Explorers and Reserve Deputies.
During the year 2010, over 1,000 volunteers contributed  over 100,000 hours to City efforts, representing over 2.0 million dollars.   Volunteers provide exemplary service to the residents, council and staff of the City of Thousand Oaks and allow the City to provide more services to residents without incurring costs.

answers.text:
Thanks for the great responses - very interesting and informative.  Have any of you used volunteers outside your community?  I work for ICMA International and in previous experience I have worked on developing the Voluntourism market in Jordan, where tourists who come to visit Jordan also work with local communities doing service projects, mentoring or other type of volunteer activities.  If you have welcomed or created programs to use Volunteers in the tourism aspects of your community - I would welcome hearing about it!

We have volunteers that reside outside of our incorporated boundaries, but are part of the region. I am not familiar with any volunteers that would be outside of our region although some of our senior volunteers only live here part of the year, and part of the year travel or reside in distant locations.

We have over 3,100 volunteers each year providing over $5.7 million in extra services. Everything from parks to children's services to animal care, policing and even clerical. I've attached a condensed Annual Report to give you an idea of the kinds of activities. For a great resource try the National Assiciation for Volunteer Programs in Local Government (NAVPLG) - www.navplg.org.

answers.author: David Marquez
answers.text:
I am currently a volunteer with the City of Avondale in the Phoenix Metro area. I assist with various projects for the city but mostly in the grants department. The projects I have received are assisting in writing and coordinating grant projects, assist in tracking legislation, and research for future projects.  
I believe the opportunity the City of Avondale is providing me is invaluable experience and allows the city flexibility to concentrate on urgent matters.

author: Abigail Lundy
text:
We just learned that it's National Volunteer Week and that got us thinking. How are local governments around the country (and the world!) using volunteers in their communities? Has the financial crisis encouraged you to use them more? Any big lessons learned or great stories you can share? Being the public servants you are, have you had any particularly meaningful volunteer experiences yourself?
We'll be asking people via Twitter and Facebook, too, and trying to compile all of the responses here. Look forward to hearing from you!
title: What role do volunteers play in your community?
